leap.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to jump high into the air or to jump in order to land in a different place
leap.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: The smaller animals can easily leap from tree to tree.
leap.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: Brenda leaped the gate and ran across the field.
leap.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to move very quickly and with a lot of energy
leap.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: I leapt up the stairs three at a time.
She leapt to her feet  (=stood up quickly) and started shouting.
leap.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: to increase quickly and by a large amount
leap.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: He leapt 27 places to second spot.
leap.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: if your heart leaps, you feel a sudden surprise, happiness, or excitement
leap.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: My heart leaped when I saw Paul at the airport.
leap.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: He threw a stick into the river and the dog went after it in a flying leap.
leap.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: a quantum leap  (=very great increase or change) in population levels
the huge leap forward that took place in the 1980s
leap.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: to increase quickly and by a large amount
leap.translation[3].definitions[0].defin: a sudden large increase in the number or amount of something
leap.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: Sales and earnings took a huge leap.
Gold shares gained following a leap in the price of gold.
